repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body: I think this naming reuse was intentional. It's debatable if it should be an error to do this if annotation typing is disabled. Static type checkers would probably reject it, though, so maybe the tested assumption itself is wrong. But it's something we allowed before, apparently.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -21,9 +21,9 @@ def main():
     foo11: Bar[:, :, :]  # warning
     foo12: cython.int[:, ::1]
     with cython.annotation_typing(False):
-        foo8: Bar = 1
-        foo9: stdint.bar = 5
-        foo10: cython.bar = 1
+        foo13: Bar = 1
+        foo14: stdint.bar = 5
+        foo15: cython.bar = 1

comment_data.body: I think this was probably intentional as well at the time.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@
     pass  # this should allow Cython to interpret the directives even when the module doesn't exist
 
 
-var = 1  # type: annotation
+pyobj_var = 1  # type: annotation
 var: cython.int = 2

comment_data.body: This test assumption seems wrong and should never have been allowed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@
 
 
 def main():
-    foo1: typing.Tuple = None
+    foo0: typing.Tuple = None
     foo1: typing.Bar = None

comment_data.body: Did you try running mypy (or other checkers) over this to see if it errors on the same issues?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -95,6 +95,20 @@ def return_wrong_type():
     return 5
 
 
+def variable_redeclared(x):
+    a: int = 5
+    a: int = 6  # not ok
+
+    if x > 10:
+        b: str = 'bar'
+    b: str = 'foo'  # not ok
+
+    if x < 10:
+        c: float = 5.0
+    else:
+        c: float = 10.0  # not ok

comment_data.body:
It seems to be consistent by default (there is an option to turn the behaviour off):
```
root@mydev:~/dev/cython/test# cat -n deleteme.py
     1	def variable_redeclared(x: int) -> None:
     2	    a: int = 5
     3	    a: int = 6  # not ok
     4
     5	    if x > 10:
     6	        b: str = 'bar'
     7	    b: str = 'foo'  # not ok
     8
     9	    if x < 10:
    10	        c: float = 5.0
    11	    else:
    12	        c: float = 10.0  # not ok
(cython3.11) root@mydev:~/dev/cython/test# mypy deleteme.py
deleteme.py:3: error: Name "a" already defined on line 2  [no-redef]
deleteme.py:7: error: Name "b" already defined on line 6  [no-redef]
deleteme.py:12: error: Name "c" already defined on line 10  [no-redef]
Found 3 errors in 1 file (checked 1 source file)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -95,6 +95,20 @@ def return_wrong_type():
     return 5
 
 
+def variable_redeclared(x):
+    a: int = 5
+    a: int = 6  # not ok
+
+    if x > 10:
+        b: str = 'bar'
+    b: str = 'foo'  # not ok
+
+    if x < 10:
+        c: float = 5.0
+    else:
+        c: float = 10.0  # not ok

comment_data.body: I think it is reasonable that cython will ignore types when annotation typing is not allowed. Whether static typing checker allows it or not is not our "problem". Maybe user even does not use static typing checker and hence we should not block him. I will fix this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -21,9 +21,9 @@ def main():
     foo11: Bar[:, :, :]  # warning
     foo12: cython.int[:, ::1]
     with cython.annotation_typing(False):
-        foo8: Bar = 1
-        foo9: stdint.bar = 5
-        foo10: cython.bar = 1
+        foo13: Bar = 1
+        foo14: stdint.bar = 5
+        foo15: cython.bar = 1

commit.message: Error out when variable is redeclared
